content: The federal government and some state governments implemented renewable energy policies in response to the energy crises of the 1970s. These policies supported research, technology demonstration projects, and commercial deployment of renewable energy equipment, focusing on liquid fuels and electricity production. The Energy Tax Act of 1978 established a 4 cents per gallon excise tax exemption for ethanol blended into gasoline, which was extended multiple times in the 1980s and 1990s. The Energy Policy Act of 1992 further extended the excise tax exemption and created a tax deduction for clean-fuel vehicles, including those using 85% ethanol (E85). It also mandated a growing percentage of alternative-fueled vehicles in federal, state, and other vehicle fleets. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 established various incentives for renewable fuels, including tax exemptions and credits for ethanol blends and biodiesel. The Renewable Fuel Standard set by EPACT Section 1501 requires increasing amounts of renewable fuel in motor fuels each year. The Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act (PURPA, Section 210) created a policy framework requiring electric utilities to purchase electricity from renewable sources, with states setting the purchase price. This policy aimed to reduce oil use for power production, promote renewable energy, and introduce competition to lower electricity prices. In the early 1980s, PURPA regulation in California led to the commercial deployment of wind and solar energy, driven by federal and state tax credits for wind energy. The wind industry saw developments with firms taking advantage of tax credits and the need for power purchase agreements for financing. This led to the creation of production-oriented tax credits and "standard offer" contracts by the California Public Utility Commission. Meanwhile, oil and natural gas prices declined in the 1980s, and Congress allowed the residential solar investment tax credit to expire in 1985. Funding for Department of Energy renewable initiatives was affected. In 1985, the solar investment tax credit expired. Funding for Department of Energy renewable energy R&D programs declined until 1990. Interest in renewable energy was reignited during the Persian Gulf War in 1990-1991. Other countries like Japan and Germany began aggressive policies to subsidize wind and solar technologies. The US Congress increased funding for DOE renewable energy R&D in response. In 1992, the US signed the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, leading to the Energy Policy Act of 1992, which made the 10% business investment tax credit for solar and geothermal equipment permanent and introduced a new renewable energy electricity production tax credit. The Energy Policy Act of 1992 introduced a new renewable energy electricity production tax credit of 1.5 cents per kilowatt-hour for wind farms and biomass. Climate change concerns led to stronger renewable energy policies in industrialized nations, with the Kyoto Protocol setting emission reduction targets for greenhouse gases. The United States had concerns about the economic impact of emission reduction targets. The United States has shown limited effort in supporting renewable energy compared to other industrialized nations due to economic concerns about the impact of emission reduction targets. State actions, like California's aggressive programs for renewable energy, have often taken the lead in implementing new policies, such as the public goods charge on ratepayer electricity use. California implemented a public goods charge on ratepayer electricity use to fund renewable energy programs. Electricity shortages in 2000 and 2001 led to an expansion of renewable energy initiatives. Recent actions include a $3 billion solar deployment initiative and increasing the renewable portfolio standard to 33% by 2020. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2007 included $1,723.7 million for EERE. The 110th Congress enacted a major omnibus energy bill focused on improving energy efficiency and increasing renewable energy availability. Key provisions include setting a target of 35 miles per gallon for cars and light trucks by 2020, a Renewable Fuels Standard starting at 8.5 billion gallons in 2008 and rising to 36 billion gallons by 2022, and new efficiency standards for various types of lamps and consumer electronic products. The Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 set efficiency standards for various consumer electronic products. The Farm, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 extended renewable energy provisions from the Farm Security Act of 2002, providing grants, loans, and tax incentives to support renewable energy initiatives. The Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 established efficiency standards for consumer electronics. The Farm, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 extended renewable energy provisions, offering grants, loans, and tax incentives to support renewable energy initiatives. DOE's FY2009 budget requested $1.255 billion for Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy programs. P.L. 110-329 provided additional funding for the Weatherization Assistance Program and a loan to help automakers produce energy-efficient vehicles. P.L. 110-343 included tax incentives for efficiency and renewables. The Senate responded to concerns about renewable energy provisions in the House-passed bill by enacting key provisions into law, including extensions for Renewable Electricity Production Tax Credit and Solar Investment Tax Credits. The law also authorized new rounds of state and local bond issuances for Clean Renewable Energy Bonds and Energy Conservation Bonds. The law authorizes a new state and local program with a total national value of $800 million for Energy Conservation Bonds. Revenue offsets include freezing certain oil and natural gas deductions, reducing foreign tax credits, and increasing the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund tax. Over 460 bills related to energy efficiency or renewable energy were introduced in the 110th Congress. The report categorizes bills by policy and issue areas, includes a table of recent actions, and discusses recent developments.
